lesson.name: Lesson 5.12: Reasoning about Exponential Graphs, Part 1

page.title: 5.12.0: Lesson Overview
page.contents:
In this lesson, you will analyze the graph of an exponential function \(f\) given by \(f(x)=a\cdot b^x\). In particular, you study the effect of \(b\) on the shape of the graph. To observe how \(b\) impacts the shape of the graph when \(b>1\) and when \(0<b<1\), you simultaneously examine several functions of this form, all of which have the same value of \(a\).

These lessons encourage greater attention to the growth factors of the different functions, rather than on interpreting the quantities in context. Since you are focusing mainly on understanding how varying \(b\) impacts the graph, you are looking at the structure of an exponential function and its graph.

When you finish this lesson, you will be able to:

  • Describe the effect of changing \(a\) and \(b\) on a graph that represents \(f(x)=a\cdot b^x\).
  • Use equations and graphs to compare exponential functions.

Here are the activities that will help you reach those goals:

  • 5.12.1: Modeling Exponential Decay
  • 5.12.2: Equations and Their Graphs
    • 5.12.2: Self Check
  • 5.12.3: Graphs Representing Exponential Decay
    • 5.12.3: Self Check
  • 5.12.4: Possible Equation for a Function on a Graph

After that, you’ll practice and review.

  • 5.12.5: Practice
  • 5.12.6: Lesson Summary

page.title: 5.12.1: Modeling Exponential Decay
page.contents:
Warm Up Activity

Jada received a gift of $180. In the first week, she spent a third of the gift money. She continues spending a third of what is left each week thereafter. Which equation best represents the amount of gift money \(g\), in dollars, she has after \(t\) weeks? Be prepared to explain your reasoning.

  1. \(g=180−\frac{1}{3}t\)
  2. \(g=180 \cdot (\frac{1}{3})^t\)
  3. \(g=\frac{1}{3} \cdot 180^t\)
  4. \(g=180 \cdot (\frac{2}{3})^t\)

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

d. \(g=180 \cdot (\frac{2}{3})^t\)

page.title: 5.12.2: Equations and Their Graphs
page.contents:
Activity

  1. Each of the following functions, \(f\), \(g\), \(h\), and \(j\), represents the amount of money in a bank account, in dollars, as a function of time \(x\), in years. They are each written in the form \(m(x)=a \cdot b^x\).

    • \(f(x)=50 \cdot 2^x\)
    • \(g(x)=50 \cdot 3^x\)
    • \(h(x)=50 \cdot (\frac{3}{2})^x\)
    • \(j(x)=50 \cdot (0.5)^x\)

    a. Use graphing technology to graph each function on the same coordinate plane. It may be helpful to use a different color for each function.

    Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

    Compare your answers:

     

    b. Explain how changing the value of \(b\) changes the graph.

    Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

    Compare your answer:

    When \(b\) is greater than 1, larger values of \(b\) mean that the function grows more quickly as \(x\) increases. A positive value of \(b\) that is less than 1 means the function is decreasing as \(x\) increases.

  2. Here are equations defining functions \(p\), \(q\), and \(r\). They are also written in the form \(m(x)=a \cdot b^x\).

    • \(p(x)=10 \cdot 4^x\)
    • \(q(x)=40 \cdot 4^x\)
    • \(r(x)=100 \cdot 4^x\)

    a. Use graphing technology to graph each function on the same coordinate plane. It may be helpful to use a different color for each function.

    Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

    Compare your answers:

     

    b. Explain how changing the value of \(a\) changes the graph.

    Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

    Compare your answer:

    Changing the value of \(a\) changes the \(y\)-intercept to \((0,a)\).

  3. Here are equations defining functions \(f\), \(g\), and \(h\) written in the form \(m(x)=a \cdot b^x+d\).

    • \(f(x)=4^x+2\)
    • \(g(x)=4^x\)
    • \(h(x)=4^x-2\)

    a. Use graphing technology to graph each function and discuss with a partner how the graphs change as \(d\) changes. It may be helpful to use a different color for each function.

    Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

    Compare your answers:

    b. Explain how changing the value of \(d\) changes the asymptote of the graph.

    Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

    Compare your answer:

    Changing the value of \(d\) changes the horizontal asymptote from \(y=0\) to \(y=d\). So function \(f(x)\) has a horizontal asymptote of \(y= 2\), and \(h(x)\) has a horizontal asymptote of \(y= -2\).

Extending Your Thinking


As before, consider bank accounts whose balances are given by the following functions:

\(f(x)=10 \cdot3^x\)      \(g(x)=3^{x+2}\)      \(h(x)=\frac{1}{2} \cdot 3^{x+3}\)

Which function would you choose? Does your choice depend on \(x\)?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

We can rewrite each of the functions as multiples of \(3^x\) to more easily compare them:

\(f(x)=10 \cdot 3^x\)

\(g(x)=3^{x+2}=3^x \cdot \frac{3}{2}=9 \cdot 3^x\)

\(h(x)=\frac{1}{2} \cdot 3^{x+3}=\frac{1}{2} \cdot 3x \cdot 3^3=\frac{27}{2} \cdot 3^x=(13.5) \cdot 3^x\)

Since \(9<10<13.5\), we see that \(h\) has the most money for any value of \(x\).


Video: Exponential Equations and How They Affect the Graphs

Watch the following video to learn more about exponential functions and how they affect the graphs:

page.title: 5.12.2: Self Check
page.contents: What is the horizontal asymptote for the function \(f(x)=2 \cdot 3^x-5\)?

answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Subtracting 5 is the same as adding –5. The graph is shifted down 5. The answer is \(y=-5\).
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The 2 is the \(a\) in the function and changes the \(y\)-intercept, not the asymptote. The answer is \(y=-5\).
That’s correct! Check yourself: The –5 causes the function to shift down 5.
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The 3 affects the growth factor, not the asymptote of the graph. The answer is \(y=-5\).

answer.answer_text: I am not sure.

page.title: 5.12.2: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Vertical Shifts with Exponential Functions

The first transformation occurs when we add a constant \(d\) to the parent function \(f(x)=b^x\), giving us a vertical shift \(d\) units in the same direction as the sign. For example, if we begin by graphing a parent function, \(f(x)=2^x\), we can then graph two vertical shifts alongside it, using \(d=3\): the upward shift, \(g(x)=2^x+3\), and the downward shift, \(h(x)=2^x-3\). Both vertical shifts are shown in the graph below.

Observe the results of shifting \(f(x)=2^x\) vertically:

  • The domain, \((-\infty,\infty)\), remains unchanged.
  • When the function is shifted up 3 units to \(g(x)=2^x+3\):
    • The \(y\)-intercept shifts up 3 units to \((0,4)\).
    • The asymptote shifts up 3 units to \(y=3\).
    • The range becomes \((3,\infty)\).
  • When the function is shifted down 3 units to \(h(x)=2^x-3\):
    • The \(y\)-intercept shifts down 3 units to \((0,-2)\).
    • The asymptote also shifts down 3 units to \(y=-3\).
    • The range becomes \((-3, \infty)\).

Try It: Vertical Shifts with Exponential Functions

Where would the horizontal asymptote be located for the graph of \(f(x)=4 \cdot 2^x-6\)?

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your answer:

Here is how to find the equation of the horizontal asymptote:

In the function \(f(x)=4 \cdot 2^x-6\), the vertical shift is represented by –6.

The parent function, \(f(x)=2^x\), has a horizontal asymptote at \(y=0\). For the function \(f(x)=4 \cdot 2^x-6\), the horizontal asymptote will be shifted down 6 to \(y=-6\).

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 5.12.3: Graphs Representing Exponential Decay
page.contents:
Activity

  1. Match each function with a graph. Explain your reasoning.

\(m(x)=200 \cdot (\frac{1}{4})^x\)

\(n(x)=200 \cdot (\frac{1}{2})^x\)

\(p(x)=200 \cdot (\frac{3}{4})^x\)

\(q(x)=200 \cdot (\frac{7}{8})^x\)

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your answers:

The functions are all exponential, and the bases are all less than 1, so the graphs will be decreasing. The most rapidly decreasing will be the one with the smallest base, and the least rapidly decreasing will be the one with the largest base.

Graph D: \(m(x)=200 \cdot (\frac{1}{4})^x\)

Graph C: \(n(x)=200 \cdot (\frac{1}{2})^x\)

Graph B: \(p(x)=200 \cdot (\frac{3}{4})^x\)

Graph A: \(q(x)=200 \cdot (\frac{7}{8})^x\)

  1. Functions \(f\) and \(g\) are defined by these equations: \(f(x)=1,000 \cdot (\frac{1}{10})^x\) and \(g(x)=1,000 \cdot (\frac{9}{10})^x\).
    1. a. Which function is decaying more quickly? Explain your reasoning.
    2. b. Use graphing technology to verify your response.

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your answers:

a. \(f(x)=1,000 \cdot (\frac{1}{10})^x\) has a smaller base than \(g(x)=1,000 \cdot (\frac{9}{10})^x\). Both bases are less than 1, so both functions decrease, but \(f(x)=1,000 \cdot (\frac{1}{10})^x\) decreases more rapidly.

b.

page.title: 5.12.3: Self Check
page.contents: Which of the following functions will decay the fastest?

answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This is actually decaying the slowest since 0.86 is closest to 1. The answer is \(g(x)=0.34^x+2\).
That’s correct! Check yourself: Of all of the functions, \(b=0.34\) is the closest to 0, so it is decaying the fastest.
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This function is growing exponentially since \(b>1\). The answer is \(g(x)=0.34^x+2\).
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This is decaying slower than 0.34. The answer is \(g(x)=0.34^x+2\).

answer.answer_text: I am not sure.

page.title: 5.12.3: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Matching Exponential Functions and Graphs

For each of the following, match each function with one of the graphs in the picture below.

Remember, the equation for an exponential function is \(y=a\cdot b^x\). The \(a\) will affect the \(y\)-intercept. When \(b<1\), there is exponential decay. The closer \(b\) is to 0, the faster it decays. The closer \(b\) is to 1, the slower it decays. When \(b>1\), the larger the value of \(b\), the faster it grows.

Equation

\(y\)-intercept

Growth/Decay

Match
  1. \(f(x)=2(0.68)^x\)

\((0, 2)\)

Decay

B
  1. \( f(x)=2(1.28)^x\)

\((0, 2)\)

Growth

F
  1. \( f(x)=2(0.81)^x\)

\((0, 2)\)

Decay

A
  1. \( f(x)=4(1.28)^x\)

\((0, 4)\)

Growth

D
  1. \(f(x)=2(1.59)^x\)

\((0, 2)\)

Growth

E
  1. \(f(x)=4(0.68)^x\)

\((0, 4)\)

Decay

C

Try It: Matching Exponential Functions and Graphs

In the graph above, which function, \(f(x)=a \cdot b^x\), has the largest value for \(a\)?

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your answer:

Here is how to identify which has the largest value for \(a\):

In the function \(f(x)=a \cdot b^x\), \(a\) changes the \(y\)-intercept. The function with the largest \(y\)-intercept is C. It crosses the \(y\)-axis at the highest point.

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 5.12.4: Possible Equation for a Function on a Graph
page.contents:
Cool Down Activity

Here are three graphs representing three exponential functions: \(f\), \(g\), and \(h\).

The functions \(f\) and \(h\) are given by \(f(x)=10 \cdot 2^x\) and \(h(x)=20 \cdot 4^x\). Which of the following could define function \(g\)? Explain your reasoning.

Equation A: \(g(x)=20 \cdot (1.5)^x\)

Equation B: \(g(x)=20 \cdot (2.5)^x\)

Equation C: \(g(x)=10 \cdot (3.5)^x\)

Equation D: \(g(x)=20 \cdot (4.5)^x\)

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your answer:

Equation B. The graph of \(g\) has the same \(y\)-intercept as the graph of \(h\), which is 20. It grows more quickly than \(f\) but more slowly than \(h\), so the growth factor must be greater than 2 but less than 4.

page.title: 5.12.5: Practice
page.contents:
Complete the following questions to practice the skills you have learned in this lesson.

  1. Here are equations defining three exponential functions: \(f\), \(g\), and \(h\).

    \(f(x)=100 \cdot 3^x\)      \(g(x)=100 \cdot (3.5)^x\)      \(h(x)=100 \cdot 4^x\)

    1. Which of these functions grows the least quickly? 

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 5.12.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \(f(x)\). The value of \(f\) triples each time \(x\) increases by 1 because the growth factor (or the base) is 3. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. Which one grows the most quickly?

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 5.12.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \(h(x)\). The value of \(h\) quadruples each time \(x\) increases by 1 because the growth factor (or the base) is 4. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. The three given graphs represent \(f\), \(g\), and \(h\). Which graph corresponds to each function?

      1. Function \(f(x)\):

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 5.12.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is Graph C. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

      1. Function \(g(x)\):

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 5.12.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is Graph B. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

      1. Function \(h(x)\):

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 5.12.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is Graph A. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Here are graphs of three exponential equations.

    Match each equation with its graph.

      1. \(y=20 \cdot 3^x\)

Correct!

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 5.12.2 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is Graph M. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

      1. \(y=50 \cdot 3^x\)

Correct!

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 5.12.2 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is Graph L. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

      1. \(y=100 \cdot 3^x\)

Correct!

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 5.12.2 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is Graph K. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Use the graph to answer the following questions:


    1. Written in the form \(f(x)=a \cdot b^x\), what is the value of \(a\) for each function? Insert integers only.

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 5.12.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 160. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. Which graph decreases the most quickly?

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 5.12.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is Graph C. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. The graphs of \(y=50 \cdot 2^x\), \(y=200 \cdot 2^x\), and \(y=100 \cdot 2^x\) are shown.



    Which is the graph of \(y=100 \cdot 2^x\)?

Correct!

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 5.12.4 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is Graph B. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

For questions 5–6, use the graph below:

  1. Which of the functions graphed, \(y=a \cdot b^x\), has the smallest value for \(a\)?

Correct!

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activities 5.12.3–5.12.4 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is F. Since F has the lowest \(y\)-intercept, it has the smallest value of \(a\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Which of the functions graphed, \(y=a \cdot b^x\), has the lowest value for \(b\)?

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 5.12.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is C. Since C is decaying the fastest, it has the lowest value for \(b\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. What is the equation of the horizontal asymptote for \(f(x)=5 \cdot 2^x-3\)?

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 5.12.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \(y= -3\). The –3 in the function shifts the exponential down 3. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

page.title: 5.12.6: Lesson Summary
page.contents:
In this lesson, you learned how to:

  • Describe the effect of changing \(a\) and \(b\) on a graph that represents \(f(x)=a \cdot b^x\).
  • Use equations and graphs to compare exponential functions.

Here are the activities that helped you reach those goals:

  • 5.12.1: Modeling Exponential Decay
    • In this activity, you practiced modeling a situation characterized by exponential decay with an equation.
  • 5.12.2: Equations and Their Graphs
    • In this activity, you examined how the numbers \(a\) and \(b\) influence the graph representing a function \(f\) defined by an equation of the form \(f(x)=a \cdot b^x\).
  • 5.12.2: Self Check
  • 5.12.3: Graphs Representing Exponential Decay
    • In this activity, you explored how the parameter \(b\) influences the graph of an exponential function, which prepared you to make sense of and model situations involving repeated percentage.
  • 5.12.3: Self Check
  • 5.12.4: Possible Equation for a Function on a Graph
    • In this activity, you determined the graphed equation that defined a given function.

After these activities, you completed the following practice:

  • 5.12.5: Practice

Checking In

On a scale of 1 to 5, how confident do you feel about the learning goals of this lesson?

Correct!

If you’ve answered 3 or less, be sure to reach out to your teacher before starting the next lesson.
